title: The ultimate guide to OKRs | Christina Wodtke (Stanford)
key_insights: Run experiments with as few as 30 users - the data trends remain consistent even with small sample sizes, though precision improves with scale
For free products, aim for 60% week-1 retention that flattens after 2-3 weeks; paid products should target 20-30%
Focus on solving trust and friction issues before optimizing for conversion - address the step before users make decisions
Do things that don't scale initially - rent stadiums, use WhatsApp groups, create Wizard of Oz experiences to validate hypotheses
Most analytics efforts fail because teams track measurements instead of insights - instrument properties into events to understand the 'why' behind user behavior
Copy optimization can be the biggest lever for early-stage products - tie unfamiliar products to familiar concepts
Add pause/snooze features instead of just cancel options to reduce churn for subscription products
Growth teams should focus on filling obvious gaps rather than trying to figure out growth strategy from scratch
topics_discussed: Career transition from investment banking to Southeast Asian startups
Gojek's growth from 4,000 to millions of daily orders
Why super apps work in Southeast Asia but not the US
Scrappy growth tactics and doing things that don't scale
Running experiments with small sample sizes
Retention benchmarks for free vs. paid products
Growth model frameworks and understanding product physics
Copy optimization for unfamiliar product concepts
Setting up and structuring growth teams
Generation Girl nonprofit for STEM education
Cultural differences in startup approaches between Asia and US
memorable_quotes: If someone told you in the US that they were going to rent out a stadium, pre-load a bunch of mobile devices... some people would say 'No. That's crazy.' But this concept of doing things that are somewhat crazy, but validate a point, doing stuff that don't scale, is really the bread and butter of what we did at Gojek.

Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. Real news is information that changes what you do in the real world. If you don't change what you're doing, what you are doing is just getting entertainment.
Everyone wants to go on retention... but they don't realize that users make decisions based on succeeding events. So what's one step before the user makes that decision?
frameworks_mentioned: Growth model physics framework (market, product, model, channels)
Made to Stick mental model for specificity
recommended_for: startup founders focusing on consumer products
anyone interested in Southeast Asian startup ecosystem
summary: Crystal Widjaja shares tactical growth strategies from scaling Gojek into Southeast Asia's largest super app, covering everything from scrappy experimentation with small sample sizes to proper analytics instrumentation and growth team building. The episode provides concrete frameworks and actionable insights for consumer product growth, particularly valuable for startup founders and growth practitioners.
